repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Refers to #27310 

Adds more specific instructions on how to install neovim for AppImage and pre-built archives.

If I am missing any information or there are parts I should elaborate more on please let me know and I will update the file,

comment_data.body: You are not appending the correct path of the uncompressed tar, it should not include the `.tar.gz` extension
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -93,6 +93,23 @@ The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides pre-buil
 
 ## Linux
 
+### Pre-built archives
+
+The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides pre-built binaries for Linux systems. There are a few ways to install this, the way listed below can be changed to a different directory than the one used here (e.g. `$HOME/.local/bin ` if you do not have root privileges)
+
+```sh
+curl -LO https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/latest/download/nvim-linux64.tar.gz
+# this is to clean up the files if you have previously installed it here before
+sudo rm -rf /opt/nvim
+sudo tar -C /opt -xzf nvim-linux64.tar.gz
+```
+
+After this you will need to tell your terminal where to find the `nvim` executable. Add the following line to your `~/.bashrc`:
+
+    export PATH="$PATH:/opt/nvim-linux64.tar.gz"

comment_data.body: Ah yes, you're right, dunno how I missed that. I'll fix that, thank you

+```
+
+After this you will need to tell your terminal where to find the `nvim` executable. Add the following line to your `~/.bashrc`:
+
+    export PATH="$PATH:/opt/nvim-linux64.tar.gz"

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides pre-built binaries for Linux systems.
```

I think this information can be included in comments in the next code block :)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
# You can install in another directory instead of /opt, e.g. ~/.local/bin
sudo rm -rf /opt/nvim # remove previous installation
```

comment_data.body:
Not sure why we're telling people how to use `mv` and `ln -s`. Though I see that #27310 is requesting it...

Should this go in `/opt/` like the other case?

And is `$HOME/.local/bin/`  in `$PATH` on most systems?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -101,6 +115,14 @@ The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides an [AppI
     chmod u+x nvim.appimage
     ./nvim.appimage
 
+To expose nvim globally:
+
+    mkdir -p $HOME/.local/bin
+    mv nvim.appimage $HOME/.local/bin
+    ln -s $HOME/.local/bin/nvim.appimage $HOME/.local/bin/nvim
+    nvim

comment_data.body: I saw `ln` being used when I searched what the typical ways of installing programs without a package manager were. If it should be used, then I think it's useful to include the commands, since the `nvim` command should be exposed globally (for most people.) And it's nice to list all the commands to get it set up and running.

comment_data.body:
It seems it should be according xdg, though maybe using /opt would be the better option so less assumptions are made about the system a user is using

Could probably just remove the ln command, as using mv to remove the .appimage would be fine

comment_data.body:
The command lines here and below could better align. Removing the directory `/opt/nvim`, but `/opt/nvim-linux64` is added to PATH.

I would've suggested using `--strip-components` to strip the `nvim-linux64` prefix, so that the installation path could be `/opt/nvim/bin`. Though this would be a matter of preference (I personally don't like as the `-linux64` suffix in the path doesn't feel very necessary).

Also using `-v` flag for `tar` will be very recommended: `-xvzf`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -93,6 +93,20 @@ The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides pre-buil
 
 ## Linux
 
+### Pre-built archives
+
+The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides pre-built binaries for Linux systems.
+
+```sh
+curl -LO https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/latest/download/nvim-linux64.tar.gz
+sudo rm -rf /opt/nvim
+sudo tar -C /opt -xzf nvim-linux64.tar.gz

@@ -101,6 +115,15 @@ The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides an [AppI
     chmod u+x nvim.appimage
     ./nvim.appimage
 
+To expose nvim globally:
+
+    mkdir -p /opt/nvim
+    mv nvim.appimage /opt/nvim/nvim
+
+And the following line to `~/.bashrc`:

comment_data.body: I find this path `/opt/nvim/nvim` a bit strange. It could be something like `/opt/nvim/bin/nvim` (*by convention*). And below, `/usr/bin/nvim` is used -- shouldn't we remain more consistent? Also, "globally" on Linux usually requires sudo permission so this will not work if this were mean to be a system-wide installation. If this were more for user-level (non-sudo) installation, it could be more recommendable that users can put binaries into a user or local namespaces (e.g. `~/.local/bin/`, etc.).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -101,6 +115,15 @@ The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides an [AppI
     chmod u+x nvim.appimage

comment_data.body: Would you like me to make another PR to address these concerns? Or can this PR be reused?

comment_data.body: Providing steps for every shell is not in scope. Users need to understand how to use their shell.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -101,6 +115,15 @@ The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides an [AppI
     chmod u+x nvim.appimage
     ./nvim.appimage
 
+To expose nvim globally:
+
+    mkdir -p /opt/nvim
+    mv nvim.appimage /opt/nvim/nvim
+
+And the following line to `~/.bashrc`:

comment_regular_data.body: This is way too chatty. This is a reference documentation, not a user manual. It's better to keep the text as simple and straightforward as possible, also with non-English speakers in mind. The intended audience here can be assumed to have some basic terminal competence (otherwise they are better off relying on distro packages).
Ok fair point, I'll rewrite it with that in mind

@clason  I have altered the wording, I made it more terse but kept much of the same commands. I trimmed and rearranged the AppImage instructions to follow on from the previous set of commands so `curl` isn't repeated.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: docs(install): add more specific Linux install instructions
